About Us

We are a non-profit organization dedicated to preserving the heritage of Fair Street and E.E. Butler High Schools, which were high schools for African Americans in Gainesville/Hall County, Georgia, and surrounding areas during racial segregation.

Our mission is to preserve the heritage of Fair Street and E.E. Butler High Schools, prepare the proud community’s future, and raise funds to support the community through scholarships and projects. Read More

Letter From
The President

Welcome to the Fair Street-Butler High Schools Alumni Association, Inc. website. Our organization is dedicated to preserving the heritage of the Fair Street and E.E. Butler High Schools, which educated African Americans in Gainesville/Hall County, Georgia, and surrounding areas during racially segregated education. The legacy of our schools transcends the schools' physical walls; it extends into the vibrant tapestry of the Southside community. During the era of racial segregation, the Southside became a cradle of resilience and triumph. African American students, barred from the same institutions as their white counterparts, excelled in academics, theater, chorus, and athletics at their Colored schools, as called then. Unable to dine in downtown restaurants, they cultivated vibrant social lives around establishments like Maxey's, Clearview, and Poole's (aka Dadeos’) on Athens Street. In response to the racial restrictions on movie theaters, they built the Roxy Theater on Athens Street, providing a space for joy and cultural expression.

While not opulent, the Southside transformed into a joyful and soulful community. The Fair St.-Butler High Schools Alumni Association, Inc. commemorates not only the thriving African American business section on Athens Street and Highway but also the resilience that transformed adversity into prosperity. This celebration is not just about the past; it's about preparing the community for a future built on strength and unity.

We appreciate your visit to our website and hope you find it informative and engaging. Please feel free to explore the site and learn more about our organization. If you have any questions or comments, please do not hesitate to contact us.

Read More

Appeals & Donations

The Fair St-Butler High School Alumni Association, Inc. has changed in many ways. We are now a 501(c) (3) corporation that supports the Gainesville-Hall County area in many ways. Read More Annually, we provide scholarships to deserving seniors to further their education or vocational training beyond high school. We also invest annually in an endowment that will provide scholarships in perpetuity. The Sunshine Seniors organization helps older people in many ways, including providing food security. We assist them financially and volunteer our time and other resources as needed. Preserving our legacy and improving our community is paramount. We assisted in establishing the Butler Park, Museum, and gym that helps restore our thriving community and honors those who created the legacy and heritage we work to preserve

The Mighty Tigers Are Still Roaring!!!

title: About Us
content:
About Us

Welcome to the Fair St. Butler High Schools Alumni Association, Inc.  We are a non-profit organization dedicated to preserving the heritage of Fair Street and E.E. Butler High Schools, which were high schools for African Americans in Gainesville/Hall County, Georgia, and surrounding areas during racial segregation. Our mission is to preserve the heritage of Fair Street and E.E. Butler High Schools, prepare the proud community’s future, and raise funds to support the community through scholarships and projects. Our Story Former Fair Street and E.E. Butler High Schools students founded the Fair St. Butler High Schools Alumni Association, Inc.. Initially, the Reunion Committee sponsored a biennial school reunion. The Reunion Committee of 1991 has since morphed into a nonprofit 501©3 corporation that raises funds to support the community through scholarships and projects to continue the heritage and help the community’s people thrive. Our Achievements Over the years, we have achieved several milestones in our mission to preserve the heritage of Fair Street and E.E. Butler High Schools. We have awarded scholarships to deserving students, organized community events, and supported local projects that align with our mission. We are proud of our achievements and committed to continuing our work to impact the community positively. Get Involved We welcome alumni, friends, and people who share our objectives to join our organization. You can help us achieve our mission by donating money, volunteering your time and skills, or attending community events. Together, we can make a difference in the community and preserve the heritage of Fair Street and E.E. Butler High Schools. Thank you for visiting our website!

title: President's Letter
content:
Letter From
The President

Dear Alumni and other friends,

Welcome to the Fair Street-Butler High Schools Alumni Association, Inc. website. Our organization is dedicated to preserving the heritage of the Fair Street and E.E. Butler High Schools, which educated African Americans in Gainesville/Hall County, Georgia, and surrounding areas during racially segregated education. The legacy of our schools transcends the schools' physical walls; it extends into the vibrant tapestry of the Southside community. During the era of racial segregation, the Southside became a cradle of resilience and triumph. African American students, barred from the same institutions as their white counterparts, excelled in academics, theater, chorus, and athletics at their Colored schools, as called then. Unable to dine in downtown restaurants, they cultivated vibrant social lives around establishments like Maxey's, Clearview, and Poole's (aka Dadeos’) on Athens Street. In response to the racial restrictions on movie theaters, they built the Roxy Theater on Athens Street, providing a space for joy and cultural expression.

While not opulent, the Southside transformed into a joyful and soulful community. The Fair St.-Butler High Schools Alumni Association, Inc. commemorates not only the thriving African American business section on Athens Street and Highway but also the resilience that transformed adversity into prosperity. This celebration is not just about the past; it's about preparing the community for a future built on strength and unity.

We appreciate your visit to our website and hope you find it informative and engaging. Please feel free to explore the site and learn more about our organization. If you have any questions or comments, please do not hesitate to contact us.

Sincerely,
John W. Harris
Class of 1965

title: Founding Members
content:
Founding Members

This group is the original Fair St.-Butler High Reunion Commitee f(FSBH) formed in 1991. It includes Mary Render Acree, who first envisioned a reunion. The gathering has allowed Fair Street and Butler High alums to reminisce, reflect, and fellowship continuously biennially since the 1991 reunion. As I researched to prepare this article (meaning I asked my wife Janie!), we found a pamphlet summarizing the history of the FSBH Reunions. I will spare you the boring details and provide highlights: Again, Mary Render Acree envisioned the two schools' classmates, teachers, and staff someday joining with other friends to remember and celebrate their high school days, friendships, and the school's legacy. For most of the twenty years, I lived in Cleveland, Ohio," said Acree at the ninth biennial Reunion program. "I often thought of the fond memories and good times of my years at Fair Street. I wanted to relive my memories so much that I packed my bags and moved back to Gainesville. Upon returning home, I invited a few of my high school friends to my place. I showed them an outline of my idea for a reunion and asked if they would help make this dream real." And from Mrs. Acree's foresight, the first Fair Street – Butler Reunion was born. The first committee members were: Dora Nell Randolph Cantrell, Charrie Morrow Goudelock, Barbara Jean Price Grant, Patricia Brown Hudson, Linda Rucker Hutchens, Betty Ivory Hailey, Thomas Hailey, Wanda Ann Smith Hale, Robert Lee Hale, Berlinda Turner Lipscomb, Deborah Keith Mack, Alton Mattox, Frances Jenkins Meadows, Alma Jane Hunter Shelton, and Blondine Summerour. Mrs. Acree stated, "We had no funds, so we paid approximately $25.00 dues monthly. We had a couple of fundraisers to help fund the event. The Reunion was remarkably successful, with over 500 Alumni from all across the country attending. What a fantastic group!" Mrs. Acree had a dream and moved back home to make it a joyous reality. Remarkably, her aspirations continue to evolve and touch many lives. The Reunion existed for 28 years, or 14 biennial events through 2019. Due to the Pandemic, we had a one-day outing in 2021, a two-day format on September 3-4, 2022, and a Labor Day Southside Celebration event in 2023. We are preparing to return to the original format with a grand event on Labor Day weekend in 2025. Thomas Hailey, who has held nearly every position, including President, is currently the Parliamentarian and Leader of the Fundraising team. Deborah Keith Mack, President from 1993-2001, was appointed President Emeritus at Reunion 2019 and serves as a member of the Executive Leadership Team. Linda Rucker Hutchens remains our Historian and Protector of memorabilia. Barbara Price Grant led the Metro Atlanta-Gainesville Connection Organization, supporting us until the organization dissolved. Some former group members continue to assist us by participating and contributing financially. Though her health restricts her participation, Barbara Price Grant advises FSBH BOD on many issues today. The Fair St-Butler High School Alumni Association, Inc. has changed in many ways. We are now a corporation with a 501(C) 3 Charter that supports the Gainesville-Hall County area in many ways. The Reunions are smaller than the first one as members age. However, younger and non-FSBH graduatesserve on the BOD. They encourage those who did not attend the historically Black High Schools to help keep the flame burning. We encourage you to contact us at admin@fsbhtiger.com to volunteer or select the Donate option above to contribute financially.
author: admin_fsbhtiger

title: Board Of Directors
content:
Board Of  Directors

Thomas Hailey

Parliamentarian

I began as a student at Beulah Rucker School. After completion, I attended Fair Street Elementary School and am an E. E. Butler High School graduate. Upon graduation, I entered the U S Army. I worked for the Norton Company for 20+ years. I was one of the first board members of the FSBH Alumni. I have served in various capacities, including President for two terms and Vice-President of the organization. I enjoy giving back to others and helping preserve our heritage and legacy for future generations.

Dorothy Lipscomb Weaver

Assistant Director of Fundraising

The Fair Street Butler High, FSBH, Alumni Association gives me an awesome opportunity to serve others with a fantastic group of hardworking, talented people I admire dearly. Contributing to the Fundraising Committee and previously as Vice President is my way of saying thank you to the Gainesville and the Hall County community that nurtured, educated, and prepared me for a successful career in management, sales awards, and career counseling with youth.

Theresa Anderson Puryear

Chief Operating Officer & Business Manager

I attended Green Hunter Nursery. I also attended Fair Street Elementary and E E Butler High School. I am a 1967 graduate. I attended Clark (now Clark Atlanta University). I became the first Black teller with Home Federal S & L Association and worked in various areas within the banking field. I worked for the Mead Corporation under the Mead Packaging and Mead Containerboard Divisions as a Personnel Assistant and was promoted to Human Resource Manager for 25+ years. I also worked for Aeroquip Inonac for 3+ years as the Human Resource Manager until the company relocated back to Japan. I became a member of the FSBH in 2006 and served as Secretary, Business Manager, and presently COO of the organization. It is with great pleasure that I work within this organization with a great group of men and women who all give their time and dedication to maintain and preserve the legacy and heritage of our great community.

John W. Harris

President & Chairman

I am honored to serve as President and Chairman of the Board. Because I was in the first class at Green Hunter Nursery, then Northwestern (1st shift), Fair St., and graduated with the 1965 class of E.E. Butler. After serving in Germany & Vietnam as an NCO in the U.S. Army Signal Corps, I sold, managed, and consulted for IBM for 15 years. As a consulting firm partner, I worked with companies like IBM, Microsoft, HP, Siebel, and Amdocs until retirement. My high school girlfriend and now wife, Mary, and I came to FSBH Alumni Reunion in 2005 and stayed to help improve our community. With a talented and dedicated team of winners, our re-purposed organization strives to Preserve the legacy & Prepare the future of the community that produced us. We have accomplished much through scholarships, community & charitable projects. Still, the best is yet to come with the cooperation of skilled board members, dedicated alumni, and generous friends and sponsors collaborating to achieve our purpose. Join us!

Rev. Dr. J. Douglas Childers

Leading Director of Spiritual Enrichment

I attended Northwestern Elementary School and graduated from Fair Street Elementary, E. E. Butler High, and Gainesville College. I attended North Georgia College and graduated from Brenau College (Bachelor of Science), Candler School of Theology at Emory University (Master of Divinity), received an Honorary Doctor of Divinity from the American Bible University, and I am currently a candidate for the Doctor of Ministry Degree from Columbia Theological Seminary. I retired from active ministry with the United Methodist Church in 2016. I served as an Infantry soldier with the U.S. Army in Vietnam, assigned to the 2/12, 25th Infantry Division. I was awarded the Purple Heart, Combat Infantry Badge, Good Conduct Medal, and the Vietnam Campaign Service Ribbon with two bronze stars for military merit. During my public Service career, I was employed by the Gainesville Police Department, the Youth Development Center, Hall County Juvenile Court, and the Georgia Bureau of Investigation. As a businessman, I was employed by the Life of Georgia Insurance Company as a sales agent. My service with the FSBH Alumni Board began after an invitation was extended for me to serve. As Chief Director of Spiritual Enrichment, I lead the pastors' team, providing spiritual guidance to the BOD and membership. I am proud of the Caregivers Program we created to support and assist our aging membership.

Angela Hughey

Director of Education And Training

I graduated from Gainesville High School in 1968 after atending Northwestern, Fair Street, and E.E. Butler High. I graduated from Morris Brown College, Clark Atlanta University, and Lincoln Memorial University. For over 38 years, I taught science at Atlanta’s Frederick Douglass High School. From 1980 to 2019, I was honored to serve as the academic and research coordinator for Morehouse College’s Upward Bound Trio Programs. I joined the FSBH Alumni Board in 2019 to help increase reunion participation from the class of 1968 and other GHS graduates. Because I want to help students reach their potential, the Scholarship Commitee is a natural fit. I lead that team and renamed it The Education & Training Team to reflect our extended purpose beter. My background as an Educator assists me in preparing high school students to excel and atain their life goals via post-secondary educatioon or training. Our purpose of preserving our legacy and preparing for our community’s future motivates us to implement a Mentoring/Tutoring Program at Fair Street School in 2024. We are awarding scholarships annually and establishing an Endowment Fund that will provide annual scholarships in perpetuity. The Education and Training team is a beautiful group of Alumni commited to compleng the many tasks before us. I especially appreciate the postive responses from each of you, and thank you for all your help.

Peggye Robertson Davenport

Corporate Secretary & Recording Secretary

I am a third honor graduate of the 1968 E. E. Butler High School Business and Education Career Track class! I am also an accomplished administrative expert with over twenty-five years of diverse experience in office management and business administration. I have had the opportunity to work with several company executives in local and global industries, where I managed businesses and Executive Suites; turned around failing administrative structures; improved customer retention; overhauled entire business operations to tighten focus; facilitated exceptional onboarding assistance; supervised personnel, interns, and volunteers; created a new client orientation program, and provided excellent customer service. Additionally, I established positive relationships with vendors and contractors that consistently resulted in substantial discounts! I have volunteered on the Fair Street Butler High Schools Alumni Association, Inc. organization for many years and designed several Souvenir Programs, Registration Forms, Flyers, and Raffle Tickets. I currently serve as the Corporate/Recording Secretary.

Gwenell Williams Brown

Director of Communication

I attended Fair Street Elementary School 1st – 6th grade and graduated from Gainesville High School in 1976. I was an educator for 40 years and retired from Fair Street as the Principal on June 30, 2022. I love the Gainesville – Hall county community. I have worked with the Newtown Florist Club and served as Treasurer. I am a member of the Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority Incorporated in Gainesville with the Lambda Iota Omega Chapter. I serve as the Epistoleus on the Scholarship Committee and the Chaplain Committee. I am a member of the Grady Young Foundation, serving as Assistant Chairman, working on the Scholarship Committee, and serving as Chairperson for the Memorial Weekend. I am also a member of the Fair Street /Butler High Alumni Association, where I serve as Communication Chairperson and work on the Scholarship Committee. I love working with children and enjoy serving in the community. I would love to see our community continue with the legacy and history of our black community. Our children and young people need to know their worth in our community. I plan to continue to serve and volunteer in Gainesville/Hall County community.

Frank Sims

Vice Chairman

I am a graduate of E.E. Butler High (68) school and attend Northwestern elementary school and Fair St. School. I worked for 37 years in the corporate world and retired as a Corp. Vice-President with Cargill, Inc. I think it is important that we maintain the legacy and history of the aforementioned schools; this alumni association has played a vital role in that regard.

Cynthia Randolph Brown

Event Director

I am participating in the FSBH Board because I enjoy being part of something positive and great. It requires a lot of work, but at the end of the day, it’s rewarding to see old friends and the smiles on their faces.

Linda Rucker Hutchens

Volunteer

I attended Northwestern and Fair Street Elementary schools. In June of 1966, I graduated from E.E. Butler High School on my birthday. Two years later, in June of 1968, I became the first African American to graduate from Gainesville Jr. College (now the University of North Georgia) with an Associate in Science degree. I transferred to the University of Georgia and received a B.S. degree in Education in June of 1970 and a Master’s degree in Education from North Georgia College (currently the University of North Georgia) in 1977. My career as an educator spanned over thirty years. I taught sixth, seventh, and eighth graders at Fair Street and Gainesville Middle School. I’ve also served as a GED and an Adult ESL teacher. My tenure with the FSBH Alumni Association began in 1991. Throughout the years of its existence, I have served several intermittent terms. I am presently serving as the caretaker of our memorabilia. I consider it a privilege and a pleasure to be entrusted with preserving these treasured items, which reflect our rich history and heritage.

Rev. Eugene Whelchel

Director of Religious & Spiritual Enrichment

Rev. Eugene Harrison Whelchel was born in Hall County. He accepted Christ as his Lord and Savior at 19 years old at Hickory Grove CME Church in Dahlonega, Georgia. At 25 years of age, he accepted his call into the ministry, and a new title was added to his name…Reverend. He served in the Elberton-Gainesville District for over 30 years. His second pastoral assignment was on the Royston Circuit; his third charge was on the Toccoa Circuit, and his last charge was in Hartwell, Georgia. He continues to preach at his home church and consistently and faithfully continues to serve the community. Rev. Whelchel is happily married to Mrs. Lena Asberry Whelchel with four loving children, ten grandchildren, and one great-grandchild. As a Christian disciple, he continues to be a role model for those around him.

Deborah Keith Mack

President Emeritus

I am a 1963 graduate of E.E. Butler (first graduating class) and a founding member of the Fair Street-Butler High Reunion committee. We came together to have this reunion because many of our classmates had moved away. We wanted to see them come home to reunite friendships, introduce family members and reminisce about our school day experiences. I have enjoyed working with this board and seeing the excitement of everyone. Every reunion gets more precious as we remember the past and make lasting memories. We want to give back to the community that nurtured us and provide a legacy that our unity remains strong.

Bernice Harbin Wimpye

Director of Membership

I am a 1965 graduate of E E Butler High School. My specific duty is registration. Being an FSBH Board Member is a pleasure, and I enjoy the planning and the end product of uniting classmates, families, and friends, which all make the work worthwhile. I feel that we are continually adding to our history and preserving the legacy of our school in an ever-changing world. We are contributing to one of Gainesville’s long-lasting traditions and hope to do so for many more years to come.

Barese Watkins-Hope

Chief Financial Officer & Treasurer

I am usually known as “Doby!” I have worked in several industries and have been a Visionary Operations Expert with solid experience managing all levels of multiple projects. I really like participating on the Board of Directors and especially enjoy delivering fun, enjoyable, entertainment activities during the events. My education includes: two years of Business Administration with a concentration in Accounting and Secretarial Science at Gainesville State College and Lanier Area Vocational School in Oakwood, GA. Using my bookkeeping expertise, I have also provided financial record-keeping assistance to the organization.

Mary Moon Glenn

Event Director

I was in the first set of triplets born in Lula, GA! I went to school in a small building under the guidance of Mrs. Nancy Stephens. From there I went to Fair Street School in Gainesville and graduated from E. E. Butler High School. Later, I attended Lanier Tech. After Lanier Tech, I started working at Ethicon in Habersham as a Technical Operator and retired in 2010. I have been working with the Fair Street Butler High Alumni Association for many years. I am on the Event Coordinators Committee. I also served on the Decorating Committee and with the Ambassadors of Fun. I have enjoyed working with the Association and hope the legacy of the school continue

Rev. Mary Harrison Mangrum

Director of Religious & Spiritual Enrichment

I attended Beulah Rucker Industrial School, Fair Street Elementary School, and E.E. Butler High School. As a self-employed seamstress and custom designer, my 1st annual Fashion Show was in Gainesville. While a certified Customer Service Specialist, I attended Lanier Area Technical School Fashion and Tailoring. I was a member of The Housewives League of Gainesville-Hall County, along with Dorothy B. Rucker and Carre Bailey. I served in the jail ministry of The Veterans & Community Outreach Program and have been an agent with Primerica since 2012. I received an Able Ministers Diploma, a Certificate of License; a Certificate of Ordination; a Diploma of Ministry, and a Diploma of Biblical Studies. It is with great pleasure that I work within FSBHSAA, a great group of men and women who all give their time and are dedicated to maintaining and preserving our great community’s legacy and heritage. I am married to James B. Mangrum (aka Clarence Daniels). We are the proud parents of 4 boys, two girls, and a host of grand and great-grandchildren.

Patience Lyle Jackson

Event Director

Attended Fair Street Elementary School from 1963-1968. A 1974 graduate of Gainesville High School. After completing high school, I attended Nursing School at North GA Vocational and Technical School in Clarksville, GA, and graduated in 1978. I worked at North East GA Medical Center for five years, moved to Atlanta, GA, and worked at Crawford W Long, which is now Emory University Hospital @ Midtown. I retired in 2018, rewarding a remarkable career as an LPN nurse. I was asked to join the FSBH Alumni Board. I have enjoyed being an FSBH alumni member for ten-plus years, which has been a very gratifying experience. I served as an event team member, and it has been a pleasure to work with such a diverse, fantastic, hardworking team! Being a member of this outstanding team allowed us to give back to the community by providing scholarships to students in the Gainesville metro community and having fundraisers. My most rewarding experiences are seeing the hugs, excitement, and love shown as families reunite back home for our annual and biannual reunions to continue our legacy and heritage. Several years later, I’m looking forward to this year’s gathering, knowing it will be one of the best!

Renee Windbush

Director of Technology & Event Registration

I was born and raised in Newark, NJ, and graduated from Malcolm X Shabazz High School in 1987. I earned an Associate Degree in Business Administration at Essex County College. After relocating to Gainesville, Georgia, I found employment with the Gainesville City School System and the Hall County School System. I launched my own “home-based” bakery and volunteered to work with the Butler High Alumni BOD. As Director of Technology, I ensure the board members and our membership have access to and use the best electronic tools to accomplish our objectives. I also work with the Events Team to manage enrollment and assist with all event preparations. Since joining the Alumni Association, I have learned much about the inner workings of a great organization where the members welcome new ideas and value my participation.

James Mangrum

Events Director

I am James Mangrum, and I am affectionally known as Sonny by most. I was born June 22nd, 1948, and attended Northwestern and Fair Street, finishing with E.E. Butler High School's class of 1967. I'm married to Rev. Mary H. Mangrum and have four sons, two daughters, ten grandchildren, and a host of great-grands. I am a Vietnam-Era Veteran, having served in the U.S. Army from 1968 to 1970. I have been a softball referee for over 55 years. I was proudly inducted into the Hall of Fame of both the World Softball League and the Black Softball Circuit after officiating games in Georgia, Florida, Mississippi, and Tennessee and tournaments nationally for over 55 years. I serve as a Director on the Board of the Fair St. Butler Alumni to show my love for God by helping others and honoring the legacy of the community that produced me.

Rev. Mary Ann Holman-Turner

Director of Religious & Spiritual Enrichment

I am Reverend Mary Ann Holman-Turner, also known as Granny or Rev., from Minneapolis, MN, by way of Springfield, Illinois, my birthplace. My loving husband, Arthur (Zero) Turner, and I moved to Gainesville, GA, in 2021. I am the mother of a blended family of 10 children: grandmother of 28, great-grandmother of 41, and great-great-grandmother of 2. I adopted and raised five grandchildren. Four of them have ADHD or Fetal Alcohol Syndrome Disorder Diagnosis. I became a Family Case Manager to establish and assist residents in family relationships from a holistic approach, retiring after 30 years of service.

In almost 60 years of Christian service, I have served wherever needed, from custodian to Administrator and Pastor. I received a Certificate of Ordination at Thy Word School of Theology in Plymouth, MN—earned a Bachelor of Religious Arts in Christian Psychology Degree from Jacksonville (FL) Theological Seminar, a Ministerial Training Certificate in Biblical Studies-Spiritual Life Training Center-Brooklyn Center, MN, and Certification in Chemical Dependency at Minneapolis Community Technical College Minneapolis, MN. After receiving a Professional Partnership Award, I served as Assistant Pastor at Thy Word Worship Center.

As a Director of Spiritual Enrichment of the FSBH BOD, I advise our BOD and encourage our members on spiritual and religious matters. Together with Rev. Childers, we offer comfort and assistance to our members and their families through our Caregivers Program.

Terrence Watson

Events Director

I was born and raised in Gainesville, GA, attended Fair Street Elementary School, and graduated from Gainesville High School in 1978. I currently work as a consignment coordinator at North Georgia Health Systems. Though I was born too late to attend the historic Black schools, my siblings and other family members gave me a better appreciation of the schools’ legacy. The opportunity to learn, preserve, and share the history of Gainesville’s Black high schools and work with the distinguished alumni attracted the FSBH Alumni Association. I have enjoyed developing relationships with fellow board members and alumni over the past six years. As a younger person, I am motivated to encourage my peers to join us in preserving the heritage of our community.

title: Donate
content:
Impact of Donation

We began as a social organization to arrange for friends and classmates to gather biennially. We have become a 501 C 3 charitable organization that executes our slogan, Preserve the legacy and prepare the community’s future. The small community on the south side of Gainesville was financially challenged and racially segregated with much pride and ambition for their children. Those humble beginnings produced so many successful people in all professions.

Today, FSBHSAA, lnc, offers scholarships and annually invests in an educational endowment that will fund scholarships in perpetuity. We cooperate with other community organizations and our local government to restore the vibrancy and improve the conditions of the community, assist residents and protect the legacy and heritage created by our ancestors.

None of the people who serve on the Board of Directors receive financial compensation, only the satisfaction of preserving and preparing the community we love. Because we are a full-time organization, we have fixed and variable costs and the money required to execute the projects we perform. Your financial assistance is needed and appreciated.

title: Prez Place
content:
Dear Members & other friends,

It has been a while since our last newsletter, and a lot has happened. Leadership needs to anticipate changes, adapt, and guide the organization into the future. Earlier this year, our leadership team recognized that our membership is evolving. As we grow older, fewer people are actively participating for apparent reasons. We’ve identified the need to involve younger individuals who didn’t attend Fair St. or Butler High but want to sustain the legacy and traditions. We also aim to encourage greater participation from able alumni. Our mission, to Preserve the legacy and prepare for the future, will guide our focus on the latter while respecting the former.

Objectives for 2024:

  1. Attract Younger Individuals: Use our schools’ and community history to ensure the continuity of our legacy.
  2. Increase Alumni Participation: We need to improve our communication and focus on involving classmates who can participate but have not been active.
  3. Grand Reunion 2025: Promote the event throughout the next year as we focus on growth.

We’re thrilled to announce that the Grand Reunion will take place at Lake Lanier Islands on August 30-31, 2025. We considered Atlanta and Gainesville, but Lake Lanier Islands best suits our audience and agenda. We understand that attendance may be challenging for some due to financial constraints, so we’ll try to keep it affordable through negotiations and fundraising. We urge you to support our upcoming fundraising efforts. We’ll open registration early so you can contribute gradually over the next year or “put something on it” monthly, as your parents did with layaways.

We’ve also made significant progress with our two primary objectives. We welcome new board members Kem Brawner, Erica Glenn, Heather Glenn, Carmen Mays, Diane Williams, and Maeryia Williams. Their diverse perspectives, experiences, and youth will help bridge the generational gap and ensure our community’s legacy continues. Sylvia Elizabeth Thornton Lyles and Clinton Pruitt will join the Board, strengthening Fair Street High’s historical and Metro Lula representation. They fulfill the second objective of increasing the participation of alumni. With the growth of the Board, we are confident in our ability to distribute responsibilities more evenly among the team, ensuring the sustainability of our organization. We, especially our COO, Theresa Anderson Puryear, continue to recruit more BOD Members—and active participants. If you are interested in helping, email me or contact a BOD member.

We are excited about the future and encourage you to support us by contributing to our efforts financially or being ready to help physically. Labor Day Weekend 2025 will be a vacation weekend at Lake Lanier Island. We urge you to put that vacation weekend on your calendar today and put something on it monthly. We hope to see you there!

If you have any questions or suggestions or want to help, please click here to send an email. We appreciate your ongoing support and commitment to your organization.

Sincerely,
John W. Harris, President

Class of 1965
author: admin_fsbhtiger

title: The Restoration of the E.E. Butler Gymnasium
content:
The History of the Butler Center

The Restoration of the E.E. Butler Gymnasium

The History of the Butler Center

The newly restored Butler Center existed originally as an important part of E.E. Butler High School.  E.E. Butler High School opened in August 1962 with 515 students, 18 teachers, 1 librarian, Mrs. Clara Poole, 1 counselor, Mr. Charles Morrow, and 1 principal, Mr. (AKA) Dr. Ulysses Byas. The physical structure at that time was a “sight to behold.”  E.E. Butler High School was described as “first class” and “state of the art”,

Contagious excitement appeared to envelop all entering the building for the first time. Students could barely contain their enthusiasm as they anticipated being able to use the new French language lab, the new library stocked with new titles, the business department/typing room, the home economics department with new appliances, and the new gymnasium equipped with dressing rooms, lockers, a bright shiny new floor and pull-out bleachers for seating. Students, teachers, parents, and the Southside community considered themselves “stakeholders” in E.E. Butler High School. Consequently, “school pride” escalated to an all-time high. Student attendance increased to the extent that eight additional air-conditioned classrooms with a new carpeted library had to be constructed only four short years later. The school quickly took its place alongside of the church as a major hub of the Southside Community.

E. E. Butler High School’s tenure as a high school ended in 1969 when it closed, and its students were integrated into Gainesville High School and various other county schools. After the school’s closing, the building was purchased by Ninth District Opportunity. A portion of the building became the site of Ninth District Opportunity’s Daycare, Pre-K, and Head Start programs. The Butler gymnasium served as a community recreation center operated by the Gainesville Parks and Recreation Department for several years. The classrooms located in that wing of the building were used for conducting GED Classes, Step Aerobics, and various other classes.

Later, the section of the building housing the gymnasium and the area classrooms fell into disrepair and was sadly abandoned. The Concerned Citizens of Hall County, the Newtown Florist Club, and various other Southside community organizations lobbied city and county officials for years to restore the gymnasium and this portion of the building. Finally, in 2021, the Gainesville City School System graciously consented to use a portion of the grant money allotted to the system to fund the renovation of Butler. Subsequently, Gainesville City Schools and Ninth Congressional District Opportunity reached an agreement. Ninth District Opportunity agreed to lease the renovated Butler Center to Gainesville City Schools for afterschool, evening, and weekend use.

The Butler Center

On Saturday, September 16, 2023, a ribbon-cutting ceremony was held in the newly renovated gymnasium of the E.E. Butler Center.  Fair Street-Butler Alumni and others displayed the school’s colors and filled the gymnasium to observe the transformation of the building and to witness the ribbon cutting. The Center comprises a gymnasium with four basketball goals, roll-out bleachers for seating, five office spaces, and a conference room on the lower level. The upper level has a concession stand, three large classrooms, and a large display case containing E.E. Butler High School’s memorabilia.

The Butler Center is currently being used by the Boys and Girls Club of Lanier in the afternoons until its club is completed at its Positive Place site. The Center’s function is no longer limited to recreation. Director Kyndra Cohen collaborates with Hall County Family Connection Network to implement programs and services that address the problems and needs impacting area individuals, children, and families. Problematic issues being addressed are food insecurity, lack of housing, healthcare, and education.  Plans for the Butler Center include afterschool and weekend tutorial programs for students, GED evening classes, senior fitness classes, and other activities designed for students, individuals, and families.

Programs have been planned and conducted to inform the community and public of the Center’s resources. However, African American participation in these programs has been minimal. Our African American community’s organizations, leaders, and members worked tirelessly and were instrumental in restoring the E.E. Butler Center. Therefore, it is imperative that we, the African American community, support and avail ourselves of the services and programs offered by the Center when and if needed.

The Fair Street-Butler High Alumni Association is enthusiastically preparing for our 2025 Fair Street-Butler High Reunion. It is being heralded as the “greatest reunion of them all.” As we prepare to support and attend this reunion, let us recall and rekindle our “Fair Street and E.E.Butler High Schools’ pride by encouraging our fellow alumni, relatives, friends, neighbors, residents, and others to participate in and utilize the programs and services provided by the restored Butler Center.

Linda R. Hutchens
author: admin_fsbhtiger

title: Good News for All
content:
It's a Beautiful World…It's a Beautiful City…It's a Beautiful Gainesville. A beautiful city where we grew up or where we have migrated to – there is nothing like home.

The Fair Street Butler High Alumni Association, Inc., is the foundation of our beloved community. In the past, we came home every two years to organize and host a reunion. We plan to make the reunion in 2025 the best one yet. Please mark August 30, 2025, through August 31, 2025, on your calendar as a 2-day event-filled vacation. Start planning now to attend this historic gala event! Please begin planning now if you need a payment plan or any other assistance. We encourage everyone to consider this as your mini 2025 vacation. Get excited and mark this date on your calendar TODAY. Stay tuned for future updates about the Reunion 2025.

Since the 2019 Reunion, we have participated in various events highlighting our community commitment. Our impact has been significant, from celebrating the newly renovated E. E. Butler Center & Park to supporting the Cros & Socks events, the Southside celebration, and the recognition of Mr. Nathaniel Shelton. We have also provided scholarships, assisted families during Christmas, supported kids' extracurricular activities through volleyball participation and organized New Year’s Eve celebrations and fish fries. Our partnership with The Hall County Black History Society showcases our commitment to the Hall County/Gainesville community.

We are deeply grateful for your support over the years and today. Your continued support of our endeavors keeps us going, and we look forward to it in the future.

Theresa Anderson Puryear
author: admin_fsbhtiger

title: The Fallacy of Human Power
content:
“Now, a certain man named Simon had previously practiced magic in the city and amazed the people of Samaria… (Acts 8: 9)       

            Several years ago, a movie entitled Conan the Barbarian was filmed.  In this film, Arnold Schwarzenegger plays the part of the protagonist, Conan the Barbarian.  As a child, Conan watched as a villain—played by James Earl Jones, murdered his parents. Conan determined that he would have his revenge one day. He prepared himself for when he would meet this villain again—years passed. In time, Conan meets the villain and has an opportunity to avenge his parent's death.  But when the antagonist realizes he's about to be defeated by Conan, he demonstrates a new power he has mastered:  he looks upward to the top of a high cliff where a young peasant girl stands. He waves his arms, captures her attention, and beckons her to come to him. Without a moment of hesitation, the young lady jumps off the cliff and falls to her death.  This story demonstrates humans' futile desire to have power and control over other people.

            In a real sense, the story of Simon the Sorcerer is a retelling of the story of Conan the Barbarian. Simon the Sorcerer, also known as Simon Magus or Simon of Gitta, is a minor figure in the New Testament. Simon was a magician and a religious figure in 1st-century Samaria. He performed magic tricks that amazed the people around him.  The people referred to Simon as having "The Great Power of god." When Philip the Evangelist told the Samaritans about Jesus Christ, many people believed and were baptized.

Still, Simon remained spiritually in control of the people. After Philip baptized him, Simon offered to buy the power he had witnessed used by the Holy Spirit. He wanted that power invested within himself—to transmit the Holy Spirit from the Apostles Peter and John. Upon making his request, Peter responded, "May your silver perish with you because you thought you could obtain the gift of God with money."  This kind of thinking is not so foreign to us today. We have religious shows on television starring preachers who have convinced their followers that they have the gift of healing when, sometimes, they have no gift whatsoever. Do you remember how Reverent Ike used to sell towels or an imprint of his hand for money?

            We live in a world of greed, where abundant lust for power surrounds us. This warped society contributes to human growth, causing many of us to turn to the wrong source in a vain effort to find fulfillment. Many today have a worldview framed as a fabricated world of make-believe—the same world that Simon the Sorcerer chose to live in. But the good news today is that contrary to the sophistication of the modern world, there is a Savior who lived and walked the dusty road of Palestine in the first century, an ancient world, but Jesus Christ is still the One to whom we must turn if we are to advance any sense of fulfillment within the crevice of our soul. It is a fallacy to believe that money is the source of human happiness or that achieving power and influence will improve your life.

The Reverend Dr. Douglas Childers graduated from E. E. Butler High School in 1968 and is a member of the FSB Board of Directors and the Spiritual Committee.

title: Erica Glenn Bio
content: Ms. Erica Glenn, a dedicated Grants Program Consultant for Title IX, Part A- McKinney-Vento Education for Homeless Children and Youth in the Federal Program Division at the Georgia Department of Education (GaDOE), is a shining example of commitment. Her role involves providing guidance and technical assistance to state agencies and districts nationwide, which she undertakes with unwavering dedication. Before her current role, Ms. Glenn made significant contributions at the Georgia Heart Institute in the Electrophysiology Department within the Northeast Georgia Health System. A native of Gainesville, Georgia, she earned her Bachelor of Science (BS) in Biology in May 1996 and a Master of Arts in Teaching Degree (MAT) in the Natural Sciences in May 1998 from Grambling State University in Louisiana. Erica is a proud Delta Sigma Theta Sorority Inc. member, serving as the Second Vice President and advisor to Tau Eta at Brenau University and Zeta Psi at the University of Georgia. Erica's interests include reading and traveling, and she is the proud mother of one son and one grandson. Her motto, "Work in Faith, NOT in FEAR," reflects her fearless approach to life and work. Despite not attending the schools, she is a proud Southsider from out the road. She is enthusiastic about serving on the FSBH Board to ensure the continuity of the community legacy.
author: admin_fsbhtiger

title: Sylvia Elizabeth Lyle Bio
content:
I began my educational journey in a one-room elementary school in Lula, Georgia, where Dr. Nancy Stephens was the principal and teacher. My schooling continued at Fair Street for elementary and high school, and in 1962, I proudly graduated from Fair Street as part of the final high school class to do so before the transition to E.E. Butler High. After completing my education, I continued to reside in the bustling city of Lula, Hall County, Georgia. I have dedicated 57 years of my life to serving at North Georgia Medical Center.
My passion for people has been a driving force throughout my career & life, and I eagerly anticipate the opportunity to contribute as a team member. Drawing on my unique perspective as the sole graduate of Fair Street on the BOD, I aim to help guide the organization in recognizing and honoring the legacies of both schools. I am committed to preserving the rich heritage that began at Dear Ole Fair Street and continued at Dear Butler High, and together, we will strive to enhance their legacies and uplift our community.
author: admin_fsbhtiger

title: Kem Brawner Bio
content:
My name is Kem Brawner, and I am the proud son of Cleo Brawner and Vera Mae Harrison Brawner. Growing up in a large family with four sisters and a brother, I experienced a childhood filled with love, laughter, and shared memories. My early education occurred at Fair Street School, where I attended through the 7th grade. I eagerly anticipated becoming an E.E. Butler Tiger but was disappointed when the school closed. Instead, I moved on to Gainesville Jr. High and graduated from Gainesville High School in 1975.

I continued my education at Gainesville Junior College, now known as North Georgia University, and later at the prestigious HBCU Savannah State College. My professional journey led me to a fulfilling 30-year career at Jackson Electric Membership Corporation, where I gained invaluable experience and built lasting relationships. Following my retirement, I ventured into entrepreneurship and now proudly own A&B Janitorial Service, where I continue to serve my community with dedication and integrity.

Driven by a deep desire to help others, I actively participate in a men’s prayer group and the Sunshine Seniors, where I find joy in supporting and uplifting others. I am also a devoted member of the Faith Christian Worship Center, where my faith continues to guide and inspire me.

Although I never had the chance to attend Butler as I had hoped, I am committed to supporting the Alumni group in preserving its rich legacy. I look forward to contributing to the community and ensuring that the spirit of Butler lives on for future generations.

title: Diane Shields Williams
content:
I am Diane Shields Williams, and my educational journey began at Fair Street Elementary School in 1963. In 1975, I proudly graduated from Johnson High. Throughout my academic pursuits, I attended the University of North Georgia (formerly Gainesville Jr College), Brenau University (formerly Brenau Women's College), and Lanier Technical School, where I earned a TCC Certification in Early Childhood Education.

My professional experience is diverse and rich. I spent a decade working in plant operations and human resources for the Leece-Neville Division. I also served as a lead teacher in several children's daycares. Subsequently, I embarked on a 23-year career at Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, initially in customer service as an underwriting assistant and later as a senior automobile rater. In addition to my corporate roles, I am a dedicated substitute teacher for both Hall County School District and Gainesville City School System.

 Recently, I joined the Fair Street-Butler High School Alumni Association, where I contribute to the Communications and Membership Team. Planning and preparation are my key strengths, and I take great pleasure in creating, organizing, and executing thoughtful solutions, always with contingency plans in mind. This will help us increase and serve our membership while providing better two-way communications.

Being part of the Fair Street-Butler High School Alumni Association holds deep meaning for me. It allows the history of our past to inform and enrich the present. I am grateful for the opportunity to contribute to our Community Legacy and look forward to continuing the journey together.

 My guiding principles encapsulate the motto: Live While We Can, Laugh Often, and Love More.
author: admin_fsbhtiger

title: Heather Glenn Bio
content: Ms. Heather Glenn, a diligent employee at Just People, Inc., has a rich professional background. Before her tenure at Just People, Inc., she was an Administrative Assistant at the Main Hall County Library. In addition to her professional pursuits, she is the proud proprietor of A New Day House in Dawsonville, GA. Hailing from Gainesville, Georgia, she holds a Business Administration (BA) degree from Georgia Southern University, which she earned in May 2000. When not engaged in her professional endeavors, she indulges in her cooking, reading, and traveling passions. Her culinary expertise extends to catering various events, including all Fair St.-Butler Alumni gatherings. Heather will now contribute to her community as a Board Member, pivotal in upholding the organization's legacy and serving the local populace.

title: North Georgia Black Business Alliance
content:
From the Desk of Angela Middleton, North Georgia Black Business Alliance, President


The North Georgia Black Business Alliance (NGBBA), established in 2023, fosters economic empowerment, business growth, and community development among Black-owned businesses. It offers a robust platform for advocacy, support, and networking tailored to the unique needs of Black entrepreneurs in the region.
Business Support and Expertise
One of the key strengths of the NGBBA lies in its ability to leverage the wealth of resources and expertise within its network. Members can access a comprehensive range of business support services, from expert advice on starting a business, moving from idea to product or service, technology services, and networking opportunities. The Alliance’s extensive connections within and beyond the North Georgia region provide members with valuable opportunities to access relevant business information, support, and expert advice. This support system is tailored to help businesses navigate the complexities of the market and achieve sustainable success.
Networking Opportunities and Community Engagement
Networking is at the heart of the NGBBA's activities. The Alliance offers a robust calendar of professional and social events designed to foster valuable business connections and opportunities. Members can engage with other business leaders, potential partners, and key stakeholders through these events, creating a dynamic community of like-minded individuals committed to mutual growth and success. The NGBBA also emphasizes the importance of community engagement, encouraging members to participate in non-profit events and contribute to the betterment of the wider community.


Exclusive Member Benefits

Membership in the NGBBA comes with a host of exclusive benefits tailored to meet the diverse needs of its members. These benefits include unique fee structures, discounts on various services, and invitations to member-only events. The Alliance offers several membership levels, each designed to cater to different business sizes and sectors, ensuring every member can find a package that suits their needs. From students to corporate partners, the NGBBA provides a membership option for everyone invested in the growth and development of Black businesses in North Georgia.
A Vision for the Future
The NGBBA's vision is clear: to create a vibrant and inclusive economy in North Georgia where businesses thrive, entrepreneurs flourish, and communities prosper. This vision is underpinned by a mission to empower businesses, entrepreneurs, and communities through education, resources, and other means. The Alliance is not just about business; it’s about building a strong, resilient, and inclusive community that uplifts everyone involved.
Join the Movement
As the NGBBA continues to grow and expand its reach, it invites all who share its vision to join the movement. Whether you are an entrepreneur looking to take your business to the next level, a community leader eager to make a difference or an ally committed to supporting Black businesses, the North Georgia Black Business Alliance offers a place for you. Together, we can build a future where economic empowerment and community prosperity are the norms, not the exceptions.
For more information on membership and how to get involved, visit
http://ngbba.org.
Contact us at ngbballiance@gmail.com
Follow us on Facebook: North Georgia Black Business Alliance (Facebook link )

title: Clinton Pruitt Bio
content: My name is Clinton Pruitt, and I am proud to hail from Lula, Georgia. Throughout my career, I have dedicated over 40 years to serving my country and community. This extensive service includes 26 years in the United States Army and National Guard and 41 years with the U.S. Postal Service. I am thrilled to bring my unwavering passion for service to my classmates and friends by officially joining the Fair St. Butler Alumni Board of Directors. I am deeply rooted in my community, and I am currently employed by the Atlanta Braves. My educational journey led me through Fair St. and Butler High, culminating in graduation alongside my exceptional classmates in 1965. During this time, I actively contributed to establishing and upholding the traditions of pride and excellence that originated at Fair St. and endured until the closure of Butler High. I am eager to contribute to preserving this rich legacy and enhancing our community through my dedicated service. My commitment to service extends beyond my professional career and education. I am passionate about leveraging my experiences and skills to impact the lives of those around me positively. Joining the Fair St. Butler Alumni Board of Directors is an exciting opportunity for me to continue this mission and contribute to the betterment of our community. I look forward to collaborating with fellow board members and leveraging our collective experiences to uphold the esteemed traditions of Fair St. and further enhance the legacy of Butler High. With great pride and enthusiasm, I embark on this next chapter of service, and I am committed to making a meaningful difference for our alma mater and the broader community.

title: Prez Says
content:
I truly valued the amazing chance to explore the world before my retirement. Each trip to Paris, Prague, New York and other stunning places was a gem. However, as my career came to an end, I realized that every journey could be my last time to that city. This understanding only heightened my excitement about being there, even though I often felt that I loved being there, but not getting there, as travel had become a burden.  I now carry this same feeling into our reunions. While our gatherings have become smaller for various reasons, I realize that each one could be my last. This thought is not a burden; instead, it fuels my enthusiasm for Reunion 2025! Knowing it might be the last one, I am determined to make the most of every moment at this gathering. I eagerly look forward to the hard work over the next four months as we plan to make this the best reunion ever! Imagine this: a two- or three-day getaway at the beautiful Lake Lamier Island, arriving on Saturday to reconnect with that old friend from Northwestern (first shift). I can already taste that delicious hamburger while playing a Bid Whist Boston with Big Rob, my partner from Race Street. I can't wait to see friends dance the Watusi, Mashed Potatoes, or the Swim to win the dance contest. The guest speakers at the worship service and the lovely sit-down meal at the closing brunch are also highlights I’m excited about. Luau Luau Reunion 2025 may be my last, so it must be the BEST ONE! Are you ready to join us? 

If you've been to the grocery store lately, you're likely aware that prices have skyrocketed, making everything more expensive than ever. A meal for two at McDonald's now costs more than I used to spend at Kroger's! Similarly, this meeting will be the most extravagant yet, and it will also be the costliest. Approximately 100 people attended our last full reunion in 2019, paying $185 each, resulting in a loss of over $11,000. Funds from the golf tournament helped cover the remaining balance. With similar attendance, we need to raise the admission price from $185 to $300 per person to break even. We also need to gather enough funds to support our charity projects, scholarships, educational endowments, and operational expenses. The Board of Directors is committed to working hard to lower the admission price. Although they will volunteer their time, the Directors and their guests will also need to pay to attend. We will also sell raffle tickets and memory ads in the program book to raise money specifically to reduce your admission price to $230, which aligns with the 23.5% inflation rate since 2019. While the price is significant, it is reasonable and necessary. So, make the decision now to enjoy a mini vacation with us on August 30-31! You can arrive a day early or extend your stay, as Mary and I plan to do. Be sure to reserve your hotel room if you haven’t already, as we have already increased the number of rooms three times.

title: Willie Mitchell
content:
**Willie Mitchell: A Legacy of Service to Gainesville City Schools**

Willie Mitchell stands as a pillar of education and community service in Gainesville, Georgia. With an impressive tenure that spanned over three decades, he is celebrated for his unwavering commitment to the Gainesville City School System. Since first being elected to the Gainesville City School Board in 1990, Mitchell has dedicated his life to advocating for students, particularly those from underserved communities, ensuring they receive the equitable opportunities they deserve.

During his 34 years on board

Mitchell’s leadership was marked by compassion and resilience. His numerous re-elections speak volumes about the trust and respect he has earned from the community, highlighting his tireless efforts to elevate the educational landscape for all students. He is particularly admired for his relentless advocacy on behalf of marginalized students, tirelessly working to meet their diverse needs within the school system.

Mitchell's connection to the Gainesville schools is deeply personal. He is a proud alumnus of the original Fair Street School and graduated from E.E. Butler High School, both historic institutions that served as all-Black community schools during the era of racial segregation. This rich educational history underlines his commitment to the very system that shaped him and many others in our community.

In a fitting tribute to his remarkable service, the Gainesville City School System honored Mitchell by naming a road "Willie Mitchell Drive" at Fair Street International Academy. This gesture carries special significance for him, as the street borders land that was once owned by his family but was unjustly taken by the state for the construction of Downey Boulevard.

Willie Mitchell's legacy extends far beyond his years of service; it is a testament to the profound impact one individual can have on a community. His dedication has not only transformed the lives of countless students but has also forged a brighter future for the Gainesville school system. For generations to come, his contributions will continue to inspire educators, students, and families alike..

title: Faye Bush
content:
Faye Bush was a prominent figure in Gainesville, Georgia, known for her dedicated community activism. She was born on August 27, 1934, in Martin, Georgia, and moved to Gainesville in 1948. A member of St. Paul United Methodist Church, she became the executive director of the Newtown Florist Club in the early 1970s. Under her leadership, the organization transformed from a group that provided flowers for Newtown funerals into a significant environmental advocacy group focused on fighting for community rights, equality and legacies.

Ms. Bush was a staunch advocate for youth development and worked tirelessly for social, economic, and environmental justice. She played a vital role in promoting civil rights and equality in her community. Among her many contributions, she spearheaded the renaming of Myrtle Street to Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard and helped establish Ruby Wilkins Park to enhance her neighborhood. She aMs. Bush was a dedicated advocate for youth development and worked tirelessly for social, economic, and environmental justice. She played a crucial role in promoting civil rights and equality within her community. Among her many contributions, she led the effort to rename Myrtle Street to Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard and helped establish Ruby Wilkins Park to improve her neighborhood. Additionally, she organized the annual Martin Luther King Jr. Day marches and championed voting rights.lso organized the annual Martin Luther King Jr. Day marches and championed voting rights.

Faye Bush passed away peacefully in her sleep on January 24, 2025. Her legacy is defined by her dedicated service to the community, particularly in advocating for youth and civil rights. Her contributions will continue to inspire educators, students, and families for generations to come. She was my neighbor, mentor, and trusted friend whom I honor today.

Throughout her life, Faye dedicated herself to the young people in her community. She created numerous programs to engage youth, including the Girls Leadership Program, Bright Teens United for a Future (BTUFF), annual summer programs, and the Youth Bucket Brigade. In recognition of her efforts, she received the Liberty Bell Award, which honors a non-lawyer who promotes law and education. Additionally, the Gainesville City Council declared “Willie Faye Bush Day” in her honor and named a street in the Newtown Community, “Willie Faye Bush Street.”

I will never forget my neighbor, mentor, and friend for the impact she had on our community.

title: The Idolatry of Money (Isaiah 55:12 )
content:
Rev. Dr. J.D. Childers

“Everyone who thirsts, come to the waters, and you that have no money, buy wine and milk without money and price. Why do you spend your money on that which is not bread and your labor on that which is not satisfying? (Isaiah 55:1-2).”

            Since the presidential election, we have stood on the edge of a financial precipice.  Many people are fearful and concerned about their economic security, as policy changes threaten to push them over the cliff should the trade war continue. Since the election, the robust economy left by the previous administration is rapidly being undermined. The stock market has become erratic, jeopardizing our financial well-being.  We are facing more than ominous clouds signaling a storm; there is also a dark, dismal spiritual tempest threatening to diminish our joy. While we may find ourselves mired in a political entrapment the trade wars can cause, we must remember that money is not a means to an end for us. There is a more excellent source to whom we can turn.

Paving Stones:

            There is an old joke about a rich man who dies and goes to heaven. When he gets to the Pearly Gates, he meets Saint Peter. The man asks Peter for permission to do something forbidden in heaven. He wants to bring some personal items with him. Peter understands the man’s sincerity and recognizes his apprehension about arriving in heaven. “Very well, you may return to earth and put whatever you can in one sack.” The man returns to Earth, sells all his stocks and bonds, converts the cash into gold bars, and fills his sack with gold. After successfully stuffing his bag with gold, the man throws the sack over his shoulder, returns to Heaven, and staggers back to the Pearly Gates. Again, he stands before Saint Peter. This time, Peter asks him to show what’s in the sack and watches as the man empties the gold bars. Peter is astonished by what he sees, almost to the point of laughing. Peter calls out to several angels, beckoning them to come over. As two angels approached, Peter said, “Hey, check this guy out. I allowed him to bring some personal items and look at what he brought: paving stones!” Gold has little value in Heaven. Gold is used to pave the street.

The prophet Isaiah says, “Hear, everyone who thirsts; come to the waters; and you who have no money, come, buy and eat! Come, buy without money and without price (Isaiah 55:1).”  

Changed Price Tags 

In his book, Who Switched the Price Tags? Tony Campolo recounts a story from his youth in Philadelphia. He explains that the night before Halloween in Philadelphia is known as Mischief Night, during which ‘trick or treat’ is more about tricks than treats. One year, Tony recalls that he and his best friend devised the perfect prank for Mischief Night. Although they never intended to execute it, they enjoyed contemplating it. The prank involved breaking into the local five-and-dime store and changing the price tags on as many items as possible. Imagine the confusion when the staff opened the store to customers the following day. Can you envision a radio selling for a quarter or a computer for a dollar? This prank would create delightful chaos!

We have different ideas about evil: how it can be shaped, how it forms, its origin, and how it impacts us. However, one fact about evil cannot be dismissed: it exists. Evil has somehow altered the value placed on human life. In my mind’s eye, I envision the image of Elon Musk, President Trump’s DOGE advisor. He’s holding a chainsaw, making animated motions that symbolically represent the slicing of the American people’s welfare.

As he does this, he shifts the values assigned to human life.  We are confused about what is happening right now. Many fear that their 401 (k) savings will depreciate, or their pensions will be reduced. Our true blessing lies in understanding that God’s values are fundamentally different from ours: “For my thoughts are not your thoughts, nor are your ways my ways, “says the Lord. “As the heavens are higher than the earth, so are my ways higher than your ways and my thoughts higher than your thoughts " (Isaiah 55:8-9). Unfortunately, people have placed too much emphasis on money.

The Idolatry of Money

Let me suggest a modern definition of idolatry: “Idolatry is worshiping anything that should be used or using anything that should be worshiped.” A primary object of adoration is money. Though we know this is true, we still crave money, and it is not my purpose to imply that money is tainted or that there’s some evil energy woven into the fibers of a $20 bill. 1 Timothy tells us, “The love of money is the root of all evil” — not money itself (1 Timothy 6:10). Money is morally neutral — neither good nor evil. It serves as a valuable tool for financial balance in our world. However, problems arise when we perceive money as something that can save us. Money cannot save us. The role of Savior has already been filled, and it was not filled by Washington, Lincoln, Hamilton, Jackson, Grant, or Franklin but by the God who holds the world in His hand, the Everlasting Creator of the heavens and the earth. The God who allowed Himself to occupy a human body and died so that we can live. If you, dear reader, desire fulfillment in a world shaped by the constant temptation for money, overlooking the free blessing God gives, you are missing the most authentic source of joy that one can have on this side of glory. Only God can set us free. Only God gives us good health, clean air, the love of family, the blessings of friends, and many other things you can recall in your reflection.

As we prepare for the much-anticipated Reunion 2025, ponder this: Would you rather invest in seeing your remaining lifelong friends again? Would you rather be there to encourage or be encouraged than buy that new phone or watch? I hope to see you at Reunion 2025.

The Reverend Dr. Douglas Childers is a member of the 1968 graduating class of E.E. Butler High and is the Spiritual Director for the Fair Street Butler High Alumni Association.

title: The Ripple Effects of Leadership: Examining Trump’s Policies and Their Impact on African Americans
content:
This article reflects my perspective, not the official stance of Fair St. Butler High Alumni, Inc. As a non-profit organization, we remain neutral and recognize the importance of individual voices. The challenges African Americans face today echo those of our ancestors, urging us to thrive in a complex world that does not favor us. Our history includes resilience, community maintenance, and an unwavering commitment to justice. It’s vital to examine the policies and actions of President Donald Trump during the early part of his second term and their impact on the African American community. While opinions about his presidency vary, understanding the real effects of his decisions is crucial. Though I edited it to be more objective, it is nearly my opinion.

Executive Orders and Policy Changes

President Trump’s record-breaking number of executive orders in his first 100 days in office surpassed President Roosevelt’s actions. These orders impacted immigration, diversity programs, and government spending. One particularly significant order aimed to dismantle federal diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) programs. Critics argue this undermines efforts to address systemic inequalities, while supporters claim it promotes individual achievement. The stakes for African Americans are high—DEI programs often provide critical resources and opportunities that help bridge education, employment, and healthcare gaps. It is also evident that this administration used DEI as a cover to attack, erode, or remove gains and achievements of minorities, women, and LGBTQ+ individuals. Trump removed the name of a ship named for Harvey Milk, a Gay rights leader who was assassinated, and tends to do the same with boats named for Thurgood Marshall, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, and others. We have ships named for the Hummingbirds, George Bush, and other less successful white men. As with anti-DEI in the workplace, it assumes that any achievement by Black individuals, women, and LGBTQ+ people is due to DEI alone, while all accomplishments of white men are based on merit. I counter that President Obama, Kamala Harris, and Hillary Clinton had to earn their achievements in a system set up for them to fail. Yet, they reached the apex of their achievements running for President and more. However, Trump and George Bush reached this level solely because of their fathers. So, I think for them, DEI stands for “Daddy Earned It.”

Another controversial executive order sought to end birthright citizenship for children born to non-citizens. While the direct impact on African Americans might seem minimal, the broader implications for marginalized communities highlight the importance of unity in addressing systemic inequalities.

Economic and Social Effects

Elon Musk’s sweeping job cuts have disproportionately affected Black workers, raising urgent questions about the government’s role in tackling racial disparities. Cuts to social programs that predominantly support African Americans have sparked heated debates about fairness and access. Reduced funding for housing assistance and healthcare programs has left many African American families grappling with the challenges of finding affordable housing and quality medical care.

The so-called “Big Beautiful Bill” is everything but beautiful, as Elon Musk has pointed out. The bill cuts aid to lower-income adults and children through reductions and restrictions on Medicaid and Medicare. It also gives significant tax cuts to billionaires who should pay more tax on their income. There are many things hidden in this bill that Congress members admit they have not read. But there is nothing in the bill to help you with daily concerns about groceries, gasoline, housing, etc. With these cuts in aid to those who need it and the firing of thousands of government workers, the budget deficit increases by over $2 trillion. Yet the President claims this bill makes America great again, which clarifies his definition of MAGA as putting people back in their places or restoring the old order.

The rollback of key protections under the Voting Rights Act underscores the need to safeguard democratic processes. Recent efforts to erase records of African American trailblazers, like Jackie Robinson and the Tuskegee Airmen, and the focus on the Smithsonian African American Museum signal a troubling trend. Despite counterarguments, policies reminiscent of Jim Crow laws threaten to marginalize African Americans once again. As you know, during Reconstruction, African Americans made considerable gains, winning seats in Congress and achieving business success. Some freed slaves received their 40 acres and a mule. When Lincoln was assassinated, the new President gave power back to the southern states, who enacted Jim Crow laws and established the KKK to enforce them. It is happening again with anti-DEI and men in tailored blue suits and red ties instead of white robes.

These actions jeopardize not only African Americans but all citizens. As Miss Mattie Moon taught us in high school, the three EQUAL branches of government—legislative (Congress), judicial (courts), and executive (President)—are each designed to play a distinct role. Congress makes laws, judges determine their legality, and the President enforces them. Yet, with Congress passing only seven laws signed by President Trump, executive actions reflect presidential priorities.  Democracies are ruled by law; dictatorships are ruled by decree. The hesitance of Congress to challenge Trump, coupled with a Supreme Court that appears overly supportive, has disrupted the balance of power, and maybe authoritarianism by proxy.. And there is nowhere in the universe where a Trump dictatorship is a good thing for anyone, but especially minorities.

Looking Ahead

Do not despair, do not comply, and be quiet as they tell us to. With the far-right Republicans in charge of the government, we can feel useless and powerless. But staying engaged is more important than ever as we chart our path forward. We had to rise from enslavement and Jim Crow. We must thrive over Trump. Our parents and grandparents fought to give us more freedom and a better life. It is now our time to give back to something greater than ourselves. The legacy of Fair St. & Butler High inspires us to champion fairness and justice, ensuring our community’s voices are heard and respected. While challenges persist, history teaches us that resilience and collective action can drive meaningful change. This is not a time for silence or fear; it’s a call to stand tall and advocate for our rights. Above all, we must vote and encourage others in our community to do the same. Despite Trump’s claim of having a mandate, he won the popular vote by less than 2%. Had we all voted against Trump, Kamala Harris would be Madam President. Voting remains the most potent tool for change. That was the reason for Jim Crow, voting restrictions, and anti-DEI. They would not be trying to take it away if it were not critical. Voting DOES matter, and every vote counts. Midterms are near; start talking to others now.

.
