title: Willie Mitchell: A Legacy of Service to Gainesville City Schools*
content:
*

Willie Mitchell is a cornerstone of education and community service in Gainesville, Georgia. With a remarkable career spanning over three decades, he is revered for his steadfast dedication to the Gainesville City School System. Since his election to the Gainesville City School Board in 1990, Mitchell has devoted his life to championing the cause of students, especially those from underserved backgrounds, ensuring they receive the fair opportunities they rightfully deserve.

Throughout his 34 years of service on the board, Mitchell's leadership has been characterized by compassion and resilience. His repeated re-elections are a testament to the trust and respect he has earned from the community, underscoring his relentless efforts to enhance the educational landscape for all students. He is particularly celebrated for his unwavering advocacy for marginalized students, tirelessly striving to address their diverse needs within the school system. 

Mitchell's ties to the Gainesville schools are profoundly personal. As a proud alumnus of  Fair Street School and a graduate of E.E. Butler High School, both historic Black community schools during racial segregation, he embodies the rich educational legacy that fuels his commitment to the system that shaped him and countless others in our community. 

In a fitting tribute to his extraordinary service, the Gainesville City School System honored Mitchell by naming a road "Willie Mitchell Drive" at Fair Street International Academy. This gesture holds special significance for him, as the street borders land once owned by his family, which the state unjustly acquired. 

Willie Mitchell's legacy transcends his years of service, serving as a powerful testament to the profound impact one individual can have on a community. His unwavering dedication has transformed the lives of countless students and paved the way for a brighter future for the Gainesville school system. For generations to come, his contributions will continue to inspire educators, students, and families alike.

title: Executive Director's Message
content:
To The Alumni Nation

I am honored to announce that I have assumed the role of Executive Director of Fair Street–Butler Alumni, Inc. Yes, we’ve streamlined our name, but our mission remains steadfast: to build on the strong foundation laid by those before us. Together, we provide opportunities for high school graduates to pursue college, technical school, or trade programs of their choice.

Our commitment to the community continues. We will collaborate with other local organizations, support the unhoused, and give back whenever and wherever we can. With a dynamic team in place, we embrace open dialogue and welcome ideas from YOU, YOU & YOU—our alumni family. We are currently planning exciting projects for 2026, so please visit our website, www.fsbhtiger.com, and our Facebook Group regularly for updates.

Meet Our Team Leaders:
- Gwenell Williams Brown – Former educator and principal of our own Fair Street School, Gwenell leads our Education & Training Team, which provides education scholarship, educational endowment, and new educationally oriented projects.
- Rev. Dr. J. Douglas Childers – A distinguished pastor and doctoral scholar, Rev. Childers heads the Religion & Spiritual Team and serves on our newly formed Board of Directors.
- Carmen Mays – A formidable leader and second-generation Tiger from the Turner family, who contributed so much to our legacy. Carmen leads our Fundraising Team, dedicated to strengthening our financial base to enable greater community impact.
- Renee Windbush – The first team member not raised in our community, Renee has become an integral part of every phase of our organization. Renee now leads the Events Team, responsible for reunions and all major events.
- Erica Glenn – Another 2nd-generation Tiger, from the renowned “Out the Road” Glenn family, Erica leads our Membership Care Team, focusing on recruiting more second- and third-generation Tigers to ensure our legacy thrives.

Beyond these leaders, we have twenty-five dedicated volunteers who generously share their time and expertise. They deserve our most profound appreciation, even if too numerous to name here.

Finally, the most important members of our team are YOU, the readers of this newsletter. Your continued support is vital as we move forward.

Thank you for standing with us as we grow and serve.

Theresa Anderson Puryear
Executive Director
author: admin_fsbhtiger

title: John Announces Reignation
content:
Historical Significance of Our Schools

The schools we represent served as pillars of education, culture, and community for generations of African American students in Gainesville, Hall, and Lumpkin Counties.

Although these schools are no longer open, their legacy and global impact endure. Preserving their memory and effects is essential to honor the struggles and achievements of those who came before us. This commitment ensures that future generations understand the importance of these institutions and the role they played in shaping our community.

Introduction

I am honored to announce my transition from President of Fair St. Butler High Schools

Alumni Association, Inc. (FSBHSAA) to Chairman of the Board of the newly established Fair St.-Butler Alumni, Inc. (FS-BA). This decision comes after thoughtful reflection and a deep commitment to our organization's future. One reason for my stepping aside is to allow different people, some who did not attend our schools but are part of our community, to continue the legacy for future generations. My choice is rooted in the belief that this new structure will empower us to achieve even greater impact, foster innovation, and ensure the long-term sustainability of our mission.

Benefits to the Organization

  • Stronger Leadership: The new structure enables us to leverage the strengths of both the Board and the Executive Team.
  • Greater Accountability: Clear roles and responsibilities will enhance transparency and decision-making.
  • Expanded Opportunities: With dedicated new leadership, we can pursue new initiatives, partnerships, and programs that benefit all alumni and our community.

My Vision for Greater Success

I am deeply committed to seeing FS-BA, Inc. reach new heights. I am not leaving the organization I love and believe in; instead, I am taking on new responsibilities that better utilize my skills. Together, we will build on our proud legacy, support our community, and strengthen our alumni network. I invite each of you to join me in this journey, as we work toward our shared goals.

Reunion 2025: A Heartfelt Appeal

At our Reunion 2025, I made a heartfelt appeal for donations to support our organization’s mission. I am thrilled to share that, thanks to your generosity, we raised over $40,000! You can watch my announcement and appeal in the video linked below:

Watch the Reunion 2025 Announcement Video: https://vimeo.com/your-video-link

Celebrating Our Donors and Classes

Your contributions will make a real difference; all the pledges have been collected. I want to congratulate the classes and thank every donor for their support. Donations were recognized at the class and individual levels, including Tiger, Maroon, and White.

For a complete list of donations by class, please visit: Donations by Class: Donor List final.docx

A Plea for Continued Support

As we move forward, I urge all alumni and friends to consider donating. Your support is essential to keeping FSBA, Inc. financially sound and achieving the ambitious goals we have set for the future. Every gift, large or small, helps us make a lasting impact.I remind our alumni who pledged donations to please meet or exceed their commitment by paying their pledges by December 31, 2025, so we can send you a tax receipt so you may claim the donation on your taxes.  

In Closing

I thank Theresa Anderson Puryear and the FSBHSAA team for making my tenure as President a historically successful one. I also thank each of you for allowing me to serve and for your support, including but not limited to financial support.

As Chair, we all wish you a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year. Go Tigers,

John W. Harris C

title: Passing the Torch
content:
After years of dedicated service to the Fair Street Butler High School Alumni Association, President and Chairman of the Board, John W. Harris, steps down as president, handing the reins to the next generation of leaders.

In the two-part video series below, President John delivers his final address and passes the torch of leadership! His heartfelt speech celebrates the alumni as a "living, breathing history"— a community of doctors, teachers, and leaders who uphold a legacy built on excellence and resilience. He reflects proudly on a tenure that saw the association incorporated, its online presence secured, and its impact expanded through scholarships and vital community service, proving that the torch is burning brighter than ever.

As John Harris steps down, he calls on the next generation to share their stories, embrace their roots as a source of immeasurable strength, and ensure the flame of this cherished institution is never extinguished.

Watch this pivotal moment as the association honors its past while resolutely building a future, worthy of our legacy.

Part 1 - The State of the Union of the Fair Street Butler High Alumni Association is Strong!

Part 2 - John W. Harris steps down and thanks the alumni association for the honor of serving as president.

title: Scholarship Announcement
content:
"The function of education is to teach one to think intensively and to think critically."
"Intelligence plus character—that is the goal of true education."
— Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

Heading to College Soon & Need Tuition Assistance?

Apply for a Fair St.-Butler Alumni, Inc. Scholarship! We are offering $1,500 scholarships, awarded in May 2026.

We are excited to offer scholarships to support students preparing for college. This year, we will award up to two scholarships to deserving students. The Educational Training Committee is also committed to establishing an endowment fund to provide a stable source of financial support for students and preserve our legacy for future generations.

Eligibility Requirements:

• Be a four-year, two-year, or vocational/technical college-bound high school senior.

• Have graduated from an accredited secondary educational institution in Gainesville, Hall County, or related communities.

• Have a cumulative GPA of 2.5 or above.

• Submit a complete application packet by the deadline.

• Attach a recent headshot photograph to the application.

• If under 18, have a parent or guardian sign the application.

Application Packet Must Include:

• Most recent transcript.

• Three letters of recommendation (two from a teacher, counselor, or principal).

• An essay (100–300 words) explaining how you reflect the legacy and values of Fair Street & Butler High Schools, outlining your educational objectives, plans, career goals, and financial needs.

• A copy of your letter of acceptance from the institution you will attend.

Application packets must be received or postmarked by Friday, March 27, 2026.

Submit completed packets to:
Fair St.-Butler Alumni, Inc.
P.O. Box 871
Gainesville, GA 30503
Attn: Education & Training Team Leader Gwenell Brown

Download the application packet: https://fsbhtiger.com/fsbh-scholarship-application-packet/

Take the next step toward your future—apply today! Alumni, join us in supporting the next generation of leaders.
author: admin_fsbhtiger

title: Reunion Experiences
content:
My first time attending the Fair St.-Butler Alumni, Inc. Biennial Reunion was an unforgettable experience.

It was an honor to be in the presence of so many pioneers. Yes! Many African American leaders, activists, and community builders have often been the first in their fields and have dedicated years to preserving our African American history. These are the people who have shown up and keep showing up to ensure the legacy endures.

From beginning to end, the entire event was a joyous celebration. I joined in the fellowship, praised God, listened to inspiring messages, ate great food, and learned about decades of shared history involving Fair Street and Butler schools. I didn’t attend the dance that night, but I saw the photos! People were actually dancing and enjoying themselves.

I felt welcomed by all and appreciated just being in the room. I genuinely have never seen so many older African Americans from one community come together like this, and it really excited me to the point where I’ve already told my parents and in-laws, hoping they can join the next one! As African Americans, regardless of where we live, we must continue to share our history to ensure it is never forgotten.

I'm thankful to Erica for recognizing my skills and inviting me to contribute professionally to the association. I genuinely appreciate Theresa and John’s kindness for allowing me to assist and contribute where I can. I thank John for his leadership and guidance in welcoming me into this alumni association, and Renee for her help as we move forward with the exciting project of revamping the website. Let’s do this!

Visit our website to learn more and stay connected: https://fsbhtiger.com

The Fair Street/Butler High School Reunion 2025 was a memorable event at Lake Lanier Island, where classmates connected, shared stories from their daily lives, and enjoyed quality moments with family. If you've never attended one of these reunions, add it to your bucket list—it's an experience you'll never forget.

The spirit of friendship and shared history made the atmosphere truly special, as classmates swapped memories from their school days and made new ones together beside the lake. Old friends reconnected over laughter, while new bonds were formed among families. As daylight faded, everyone left with full hearts and a deeper appreciation for the lasting connections that make these reunions so meaningful.

Mary Cleveland Brown

Class of 1965

What a Time We Had at the FSBH 2025 Reunion!

Lake Lanier Resorts – A Weekend to Remember

The FSBH 2025 Reunion at Lake Lanier Resorts felt like a getaway to a tropical paradise! From the moment we arrived, the energy was electric—seeing old friends was just one of the many highlights of an unforgettable weekend.

And let’s talk about Baby Sug and family—sensational doesn’t even begin to describe it! We truly had CHURCH together. This was the best reunion EVER! Everyone put their “boots on the ground” (literally) and made memories that will last a lifetime. Now, get ready for FSBH 2027—it’s going to be even bigger and better!

A huge thank you to the reunion committee for a job well done!

Brenda Hughey & Kim Brown

A Prayer of Gratitude

Father God, we come to you once again, thanking you for another new day—a day we have never seen before. Thank you for watching over us last night and waking us this morning right on time.

We are grateful for all you have done, all you are doing, and all you will continue to do. Thank you for each Thursday when we gather at the eleventh hour to study your word. We ask that you remember everyone on the prayer list and minister to each of their needs. Help us to take heed to today’s lesson and not be hypocritical toward one another. We ask for deliverance from anything unworthy of you, Lord. Keep us safe in your arms—not only today but in the days to come. We know all power is in your hands, and without you, we can do nothing. We ask all this in your name. Amen.

Cover us with the Most Precious Blood of Your Son, our Lord Jesus Christ, from the top of our heads to the soles of our feet. In Jesus’s name, Amen.
author: admin_fsbhtiger

title: Spiritual Space
content:
Pythonic Spirit

A Pythonic Spirit

By Douglas Childers, D.Min., D.D., M.Div.

While she followed Paul and us, she would cry out,

“These men are slaves of the Most High God, who proclaim to you a way

Of Salvation.” (NIV: Acts 16: 17)

We often think of the word “spirit” as referring to a divine or holy entity; however, the biblical passage in Acts 16:16-32 shows this is not always the case. The spirit of divination was a “pythonic spirit,” named after the legendary serpent slain by Apollo, the god of prophecy. In the Acts story, we see a business owner who boosts his profits by exploiting a slave girl who had a spirit of divination. One day, Paul and his fellow evangelist, Silas, were on their way to pray when they met the slave girl. She followed them and prophetically began calling them “Slaves of the Most High God.” She was correct—they were servants of God. The greedy business owner had exploited and mistreated the slave girl’s life. That explains why she called the evangelists the Servants of the Most High God. But what annoyed Paul was her insincere proclamations. By repeatedly shouting and identifying the evangelists, she had turned her words into mockery rather than praise. This behavior troubled Paul. He decided to resolve the situation by casting out the demonic spirit: “I order you in the name of Jesus Christ to come out of her,” and the spirit left the slave girl.

The consequence of its release harmed her owner's financial interests. Nicholas Buccola presents a contrasting view of William F. Buckley Jr. and James Baldwin in his book, “The Fire is Upon Us.” Many see these men as symbols of a rising social movement addressing America’s racial issues. Buckley was a conservative who did little to support civil rights initiatives; however, studying his character can help us understand the mindset of the Republican Party and their willingness to cut programs like SNAP, which became more vulnerable after recent government shutdowns. Buckley grew up at the “Buckley estate” called “Great Elm” in Sharon, Connecticut. His family was upper-class white, raised with the philosophy of “Individualism.” Both men were brought up in patriarchal homes that valued their mothers as moral guides. The Buckley family believed in a hierarchical system and, in terms of racial intellectualism, held racist views. Buckley’s father believed that society’s elite should govern the government. Albert Jay Nock, an individualist thinker, taught the Buckley children to distrust democracy and to embrace the idea that a remnant of elites should govern society. This attitude also appears evident in Donald Trump. When I heard about Trump’s decision to demolish the east wing of the White House to make way for a large ballroom, I saw it as an elitist mindset. This behavior was evident on Halloween, when Trump celebrated with wealthy friends whom he had granted tax breaks. It reflected an attitude reminiscent of the privilege held by Gilded Age elites. While millions of Americans were on the brink of hunger, Trump and his associates enjoyed themselves at Mar-a-Lago, Trump’s elitist estate and private club located in Palm Beach, Florida. Their behavior seemed similar to the Buckley family's ingrained elitist values. Some spirits are malevolent. Lucifer, or Satan, was once called an angel of light; however, his desire to rule in God’s place condemned him as evil. But spiritual leaders can also serve as partners in spreading false messages. James Baldwin explains that the church caused his stepfather to see it as a crutch to escape the pain inflicted by discrimination against people of color and poor whites in American society. I hope spiritual leaders on our FS-BH board and its membership will be mindful of our responsibilities—not to exorcise evil literally but to exemplify qualities of kindness, love for one another, and an understanding that God is “Otherness,” and, as such, God can be found in our pain, disappointments, and frustrations. This awareness can empower us to maintain spiritually mature behavior in our daily lives.

Rev. Dr. Childers is a member of the E.E. Butler class of 1968

content:
From President to Chairman

By John W. Harris

Fair St. Butler Alumni, Inc.

Newsletter Announcement

Historical Significance of Our Schools                                                 

The schools we represent served as pillars of education, culture, and community for generations of African American students in Gainesville, Hall, and Lumpkin Counties. Although these schools are no longer open, their legacy and global impact endure.

Preserving their memory and impact is essential to honor the struggles and achievements of those who came before us. This commitment ensures that future generations understand the importance of these institutions and the role they played in shaping our community.

Introduction                                                 

I am honored to announce my transition from President of Fair St. Butler High Schools Alumni Association, Inc. (FSBHSAA) to Chairman of the Board of the newly established Fair St.-Butler Alumni, Inc. (FS-BA). This decision comes after thoughtful reflection and a deep commitment to our organization's future. One reason for my stepping aside is to allow different people, some who did not attend our schools but are part of our community, to continue the legacy for future generations. My choice is rooted in the belief that this new structure will empower us to achieve even greater impact, foster innovation, and ensure the long-term sustainability of our mission.

Benefits to the Organization                                                 

  • Stronger Leadership: The new structure enables us to leverage the strengths of both the Board and the Executive Team.
  • Greater Accountability: Clear roles and responsibilities will enhance transparency and decision-making.
  • Expanded Opportunities: With dedicated new leadership, we can pursue new initiatives, partnerships, and programs that benefit all alumni and our community.

My Vision for Greater Success                                                 

I am deeply committed to seeing FS-BA, Inc. reach new heights. I am not leaving the organization I love and believe in; instead, I am taking on new responsibilities that I think better utilize my skills. Together, we will build on our proud legacy, support our community, and strengthen our alumni network. I invite each of you to join me in this journey, as we work toward our shared goals.

Reunion 2025: A Heartfelt Appeal                                                 

At our Reunion 2025, I made a heartfelt appeal for donations to support our organization’s mission. I am thrilled to share that, thanks to your generosity, we raised over $40,000 in pledges. But we need more to meet our plans over the next two years. Watch my announcement and appeal in the video linked below. If you have not contributed or pledged, please click on the link in the newsletter to do so. And if you pledged, please keep your commitment as we need and count on your donations.

Celebrating Our Donors and Classes                                                 

Your contributions will make a real difference;  I want to congratulate the classes and thank every donor for their support. Donations were recognized at the class and individual levels, including Tiger, Maroon, and White.

For a complete list of donations by class, please visit:

Donations by Class: Donor List final.docx

A Plea for Continued Support                                                 

As we move forward, I urge all alumni and friends to consider donating. Your support is essential to keeping FSBA, Inc. financially sound and achieving the ambitious goals we have set for the future.
